comments.commentBody: Considering which individual income group owns a majority of the stock in the market, it will remove that former disparity of wealth between rich and poor and will narrow considerably. The poor have nothing invested while the wealthy control much of it and their portfolios are shrinking every day. In addition, all those state pension plans (invested in the market) and individual 401k's (also invested in the market) will ensure that any retirees will also lose their wealth and become poorer as will state budgets be bankrupt.  We are all headed to the poor house together, some faster than others.
Laurie C--it is not a third of women; it is a third of the 42% who are unhappy--14%. Pretty big difference.

We need to rely more heavily on the only real ally we have in the region: India.  India is a multireligion, multiethnic democracy which has a shared interest in containing Pakistani aggression.  We should suspend all aid to Pakistan, conduct some joint special ops with India right on the Pakistani border, and be aggressive about putting Pakistan on the UN list of state sponsers of terrorism.

Thank You Adm. Mullen for telling it like it is. For telling the truth. For calling a spade a spade. For calling a wolf (an enemy, Pakistan) in sheep's clothing. Thank you for your brave service sir.

When ever I have an opportunity to discuss what's happening in that part of the world especially to our troops who continue to face terror attacks by the taliban, in light of what we now know, al quaida for sure being sheltered, supported, not arrested or attacked by our ally Pakistan, in spite of us sending over billions to them, most of my Pakistani friends ranging from cab drivers to work associates have boldly said to my face that if push comes to shove, "America can and will never attack Pakistan, no matter what", that "those good old days are gone". I ask them how can they be so sure and I get the same response that Bin Laden was reported to have always said "America does not have what it takes to fight, its weak, its finished, people here are weak, they don't want to die, except for a few volunteers in the army, they will never stand up for any war anywhere, etc. etc. "
While I'd like to believe these Pakistanis are sadly mistaken, it certainly appears our military brass and politicians are sending the wrong signals here and abroad. At least, mixed signals of weakness and doubt over to our sworn enemies and their supporters by sending over billions of US taxpayer dollars, uninterrupted and guaranteed aid to a backstabbing and an untrustworthy ally Pakistan, who kills and maims US troops and attacks American foreign policy ever chance they get, while our leadership plays "diplomacy" instead of cracking down on terrorists and their supporters in the AfPak theatre.
Its a national shame to see our troops being maimed and killed by a US taxpayer paid killer/attacker "ally" Pakistan, while our leadership plays politics! Most Americans will tell you, the time for politics and diplomacy alone to deal with Pakistan is long gone.
God bless our brave troops.

Why US pays billions of dollars to Pakistan? I suspect it has something to do with the US defense industry. Does the aid money gets recycled back to the USA when pakistanis buy US arms?

If yes, good luck trying to suspend military aid to that country. Remember, lobbyists?

In simple terms, United States treasure has been used to pay for killing of United States Citizens.  This is so treasonous that those responsible need to pay with their lives.  Pakistanis? Too bad. Die. We need to use our drone bases to go after the murderers.

Our military continues to advocate war on distant sovereign nations even though
the USA is so broke that even if taxpayers were taxed 100% of their earnings, we could not
reduce our ridiculously bloated national debt. (Source- Stansberry Research)
How many times have we killed dozens of innocent Pakistanis, including women and children with drone attacks? Did we expect them to stand by and twiddle their thunbs as we killed innocent civilians time after time? In the History of planet earth, no sovereign nation has ever sat idly by as a foreign national attacked them. You would think, with over a billion a day spent on the military, that they could afford a history book.

Pakistan has lost 35,000 lives in more than 2000 attacks on its soil since America's war on terror began. What is happening in Afghanistan is natural; all invaders in that country have been fiercely resisted in that country. If American cannot stop militants to traverse more than 200 miles from Pakistan border to attack Kabul, can it take on Pakistan? American people should also remember that there were no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, and that their leaders lied. Could they be lying now, to evade responsibility for their failure in Afghanistan?
Actually, our ancestors not only put up with this type of stuff, but paid tribute to the pirates off of Tripoli.

It has long been time to withdrew from Afghanistan. And it has even longer been time to quit sending military aid to Pakistan. And before we end the whole thing we must do something to destroy the nuclear weapons we have already given to Pakistan.
What on earth was Bush Sr. thinking of when he gave those people nukes!!!
There is no way I think we should continue a losing war when we can't afford to pay for medical insurance and college education for all of our people.
This is an IQ test. If we stay in Afghanistan ( and Pakistan) we fail.

If we just let this horror pass we will be sending a message, that we are patsies, wimps, whipping boys. I just want to grab our "leaders" (and I use that term very loosely) and say, "snap out of it". The idea we would ever consider Pakistan, a country whose values are diametrically opposed to ours, North Korea's are closer, a friend or treat it as anything but the mortal enemy is it, makes us look like fools. Are we fools? Are we patsies? So far, the answer is yes. And it is incredibly embarrassing. More than embarrassing. Are we still sending them money? Anything? Just sickening. Everyone in charge of our Pakistan appeasement policy should be fired immediately.

Now that the US has made a statement, its time to engage Pakistan multilaterally to assist it with its continued development etc, this way in good time any future Taliban or terrorists activity will be rendered obsolete and dealt with internally by its own population with the retribution it deserves for its actions.

i would certainly be too much to expect that the u.s. accept it is failing the mission (whatever it is) in afghanistan. every passing month in afghanistan appears worse than the last, yet the obama is heard at the u.n. claiming to have turned the tide; the reality is certainly changing in the middle east and elsewhere not because of american efforts, rather in spite of them.

america is indulging in self-delusion. we cannot be seen to be at the mercy of ragtag taliban forces; let's blame the pakistan backed haqqani network. no evidence is needed to make this claim except to cite the sophistication of the plot.

deluding yourself to be the supporters of self-determination and democracy while stamping out the palestinian bid at the u.n. and deluding yourself to be winning the war in afghanistan. if we were to wake up to the reality we wouldn't need scapegoats like the haqqani network.

So we give them another $10 billion, right? Wrong!

Cut off military funding to Pakistan. Spend the money here.

This is an email I had sent my friend in India..It's crazy that two countries achieved independence at the same time and one is off and running and the other is mired in blaming everyone but themselves for their disasters. If the US had mentioned a word about their plans to get Bin Laden with any of the clowns in the military or government, it would have been a failed operation. The US stupidly realizes Pakistan's decades' long duplicity now, after pouring billions into their coffers that helped them become a dysfunctional addict. So no potential leader in Pakistan can succeed unless they talk about how they will be competitive globally on a financial scale..
All the wannabe leaders talk about is how to get America and India and whine, whine, whine. Pakistani leaders are dreadfully boring and sacrifice their countrymen routinely without a twang to their conscience. It's also that they are this stupid theocratic state and radicalize their religion to suit their sensational fantasies... Enough said.
If they do not respect our sovereignty, tha we should respect theirs.  Cut off funding100% to these duplicitous and murderous alleged allies.

Yeah, it makes a lot more sense to give $3 billion to a country that finances terrorists to kill us than, say, to use that $3 billion to foster early childhood education or rebuild infrastructure here in the US. The Pakistani leadership is culpable in this - and so is ours.

Yeah, William's question is tough. Many fathers will say they are doing it for the tradition. Football reveres tradition, and hence, I think parents will continue to urge their sons toward football, even after watching their idols from the sixties and seventies checking out early with chronic traumatic encephalopathy and reading that repetitive blows of only modest intensity, which are not detectible in the immediate behavior of the player, damage the brain irreparably. And they will recycle all of the standard nostrums about toughness and competition. But, I think the ugly truth about football will eventually prevail. Even though colleges are maniacally throwing money into football programs right now, I think football's days as the national pastime are numbered and that in a generation or two, young people educated to the deadliness of the sport will reject the traditionalist rhetoric and direct their athletic children in other directions, colleges and universities will slough off expensive programs (as pools of gridiron bound alums shrink) and professional football will become a sort of violent and bizarre sideshow.

I enjoyed this puzzle, and did well except in the SE, where I finally revealed 46A to help me through the rest.

Was an Avon Lady myself while in high school. I'd ring someone's doorbell, announce myself with "Avon calling", and they would almost invariably laugh. I certainly did not look the part; people thought I was about 12, and I didn't wear makeup or stereotypical Avon Lady clothes. Made about $75 a week one summer, which wasn't terrible in the 60s.
What an wonderful puzzle this was.  It was a challenge right up to the final letter--and 44 down made me lowph out loud.  Mike Nothnagel, you are a riot!
@Deb ROLF definitely would not lead on to be ROFL

Would have preferred Antonio Carlos Jobim to Quincy Jones, but that's fine.  As for the puzzle, the LEROUX, LAMA, MEA group was a triple natick for me, though I did manage to finish the NE despite my original ALLOW for ENDOW and GESSO for TORSO.  Ya gotta love a Nothnagel.

This is my first post. I don't even know if anyone reads additional comments this far back. In enjoyed the puzzle; didn't get every word (Coe College?). I was proud of taking one look at the chemical formula in 87D and knowing the answer. I've heard "nutsy", but never "nutso".
I wonder about "The" in 14D; it's unnecessary and isn't ever included in the clue unless it's to be in the answer.
I'm about to add some rants to the comments on the Sep. 4 puzzle.
I think this is excellent. A touch of class from the stands -- what a shocker. Maybe they should try that at the Copa Sudamericana.

Get a dog and you will find yourself strolling, running, throwing and swimming.

A dog will get even the most sedentary person out of the house - and many of us even talk to our dogs!
